stories.text:
I have owned a business doing tech for my entire adult life. I recently (over a year ago) took a job for the first time in 20 years, my other business I sold most of it off, and maintain a few customers. I am doing IT related stuff in the new job (right up my alley). But the key reason I came on board was the offer of ownership.

Future ownership as an option has been rescinded this past week.

The job is a good job, the people I work with are great, there is likely a really bad boss coming in 10 years or so. (complicated) Pay is decent. I've not been in the job market ever really (since college), and I only took this job because it was a business building opportunity, not just IT.

How should I be looking at this? I will get a chunk of cash buyout sometime in the new few years, but I can't retire on it. But I won't have anymore skin in the game.

I could leave right now, and I still get my buyout (unusual arrangements I made) and go back to starting another business. Heck, even resurrect my old one.

Has anyone found happiness by just sort of giving up and just sitting back and relaxing into a job?

Any help suggestions, advice would be appreciated.
stories.title: Ask HN: Options for Ownership vs. Having a Job
A modern JavaScript router in 100 lines (2014)

stories.text:
A 1 hour meeting with 10 people could cost the company a lot of money. If they measured the salary cost of 1 hour for each person that participates then they could easily justify replacing a 1 hour meeting with a 15 minute meeting or just an email.

I have never seen such a measurement tracked.
stories.title: Why doesn't business have a “meeting cost” line item?
